OK for this next round of caramelized onion hollandaise sauce I’m adding three cubes of frozen caramelized onions so about maybe 6 tablespoons. I kept one large egg yolk and I did about 3 1/2 tablespoons of butter and about a tablespoon of water and added a big pinch of sugar. Going to be this time for longer at a lower temperature about 141°

events.outcome: Not quite jammy; thick jam; holds shape; viscous and smooth; onion flavor pronounced; needs salt.

evidence.excerpt: The previous image shows what caramelized onions, previously caramelized onions that were previously frozen and then placed into a bag with egg yolk probably about a one to one ratio of eggs to caramelized onions. It was sous vide in a Ziploc bag at 145.5° for about three hours. It’s not quite jammy but that actually no it’s kind of a thick jam. The orange is a dark orange. It holds it shape, but it’s still somewhat viscousand smooth. The onion flavor is more pronounced and need some salt.

events.outcome: thicker in the pan after thawing; color revived; flavor ~80% of original

evidence.excerpt: I also ended up freezing the latest batch of hollandaise with the triple caramelized onions and more butter. I only froze it for a little less than a day and when it came out it was noticeably thicker in the pan even after being warmed, but a little splash of cream and the color came back and the taste was probably about 80% there compared to what it was

events.outcome: Pan briefly heated to 152°F, which thickened the sauce and helped it hold shape; onion remained subtle; flavor improved slightly; more onion recommended next time.

evidence.excerpt: I heated the pan up about 152° very briefly taking it on and off the heat trying to keep it at around 140° and that has noticeably thickened up the sauce to a much nicer consistency where it holds a shape and doesn’t completely spread out on the pan the flavor is also improved a little bit but The Onion The Onion is a little too subtle we had about one ice cube tray full of it per egg and I think I may need more

events.outcome: Tried to maintain around 140°F; thickened the sauce and helped it hold shape; onion remained subtle.

events.outcome: onions browned in butter with foaming; produced a sweet, nutty butter after straining; similar effect on a repeated pass

evidence.excerpt: I had a little bit of inspiration after reading that some people use pressure cookers to get onions to a caramelization point in water. I did not do that I figured that fat could get to a similar temperature so I diced up some onions and put it in a small pan and try to keep the temperature to about 250° although it did very quite a bit during that process and over about 20 minutes it first starts to foam heavily so I probably put like 2 tablespoons of butter with I don’t know about about 2 tablespoons of diced onions. And it gets brown almost like it’s frying while it’s foaming but it doesn’t burn and the after result is a pretty sweet very nutty butter once it’s strained. And then I did that again and it got even sweeter with the same butter but by the time all the by the time you do it more than once it reduces by like maybe 1/3 to 1/4 of what it Was

events.outcome: burning spots forming; heat challenging to control

events.outcome: rapid temperature climb due to moisture loss; plan to reduce heat; danger noted

evidence.excerpt: Thanks for the update—smart call reducing the heat as the foam increases and pan sides hit 278°F with that rapid temp climb from moisture loss.

events.outcome: okay; onion flavor and sweetness were lacking

events.outcome: The onion/egg flavor was subtle and not very good at this stage; butter adjustments improved taste later.

evidence.excerpt: so it wasn’t tasting very good it was I added about a teaspoon of honey and a teaspoon of POMMERY mustard. And I mixed it and it got pretty thick and then I put it on about 145° pan and it got pretty thick but the onion and egg tastes was really subtle it just wasn’t that good and then I realized that my butter and my butter ratio was off so I added this is after eating some so I probably added about twice the volume of butter or maybe 33% at least as much butter as the actual food left in the pan if not more and that’s substantially improved the taste so I think when the flavor is off it may just need more butter

events.outcome: initial browning observed; color then stopped moving after ~30 minutes; heat later increased

evidence.excerpt: so I cooked it for about an hour after putting the oven cooked onions into the pan I started out at around 220° and that had some nice browning I had to stir probably about every couple minutes and add a little splash of water probably about a teaspoon while I was doing it to keep them hydrated but then the color stopped moving much about a half an hour mark I think and that’s when I really kicked it up the heat to about between 280 and around 300° and I was stirring more frequently adding water and adding a little bit of butter you know probably half a teaspoon at a time to wear essentially I could really crank up the heat internally and almost fry it and that really started because the deep deep brown color was basically happened when it was frying and when I ended it with a with a little bit more water just to increase the viscosity

events.outcome: deep brown color; described as frying; ongoing stirring and moisture addition

Piña learned fast. Not like a person learns, with a life spent boiling and burning, but by tasting the air as onions met butter; by mapping the delicate collapse of a tomato from orb to sauce; by listening to the octave shift of a simmer turning into a boil, the way a violin slides into the note with a small ache.
